attributes.title: The Challenge of Sexually Transmitted Infections for HIV Pre-exposure Prophylaxis Among Individuals at High Risk of HIV Infection:A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q1.value: The Challenge of Sexually Transmitted Infections for HIV Pre-exposure Prophylaxis Among Individuals at High Risk of HIV Infection:A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q2.value: Xiangyu Ma, Yang Zhang, AiXin Li, Meixia Gao, Da Wang, Shui Jiang, Tong Zhang, Hao Wu, Xiaojie Huang, Guanzhi Chen

q3.value: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a promising intervention to prevent Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) acquisition,with benefits both to the individual and to population-level health.However,with the widespread use of PrEP,there will be some changes in people's sexual behavior.Infection rates of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) have significantly increased over the last decade.Behavioral changes such as a decrease in condom use and an increase in number of sexual partners may partly explain increasing rates of STD diagnosis.This is what we call "risk compensation".

q4.value: PrEP could leads to an increase in the incidence of sexually Transmitted Infections.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We identified studies published up to September 2019,through systematic literature searches and discussion with investigators.In this systematic review and meta-analysis,we performed a comprehensive database searching in PubMed,Web of Science,the Cochrane Library,and were done with medical subject headings and free text relating to“HIV”,“AIDS”,“Pre-exposure prophylaxis”and“STIs”.There are no research type restrictions on the studies we included.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We included the studies of oral PrEP to reduce the incidence of HIV among individuals at high risk of HIV infection,compared changes in sexually transmitted infections (STIs) or high-risk sexual behavior whether to take PrEP or before and after take PrEP.To be included,studies had to report the new sexually transmitted infections rather than HIV.Study selection criteria only original studies were considered.The inclusion criteria for studies were that they were cross-sectional,case control,or cohort in design.The investigators measured any of the following outcomes:1.Any new sexually transmitted infections,such as syphilis,gonorrhea,chlamydia,HSV and hepatitis C;2.Condom use;3.Number of sexual partners.Review articles,case report and non-English papers were excluded.Studies were also excluded if they reported predicted outcomes rather than actual outcomes.
Two investigators (Xiangyu Ma and Da Wang) screened all titles and abstracts identified in the initial search and excluded studies in violation of the inclusion criteria.Two investigators (Xiangyu Ma and Aixin Li) assessed the full texts and data extraction.In cases of disagreement, consensus was achieved through referral to a third reviewer (Yang Zhang).

q13.value: We will analyze the data of 18275 participants,age of participants ranged between 18 and 68.Length of follow-up ranged 6–13months.

question.value: We included the studies of oral PrEP to reduce the incidence of HIV among individuals at high risk of HIV infection,compared changes in STIs or high-risk sexual behavior whether to take PrEP or before and after take PrEP.The investigators measured any of the following outcomes:1.Any new sexually transmitted infections,such as syphilis,gonorrhea,chlamydia,HSV and hepatitis C;2.Condom use;3.Number of sexual partners.

Quality and risk of bias assessment will conduct on included studies using aspects of the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for randomized trials and the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for non-randomized trials and observational studies.We will use Revman 5.3 software for analysis and used forest map and funnel plot to detect bias.For pooled data, the I² statistic will be used to estimate heterogeneity and risk of bias, specifically publication bias.

attributes.title: Does Tai Chi Chuan Improve Psychological Well-being and Quality of Life in Patients with Breast Cancer? Protocol for A Systematic Review of Randomized Controlled Trials
attributes.description: Breast cancer is now the most common cancer diagnosed in women and is the leading cause of deaths from cancer among women. Studies have shown that exercise reduces the risk of breast cancer development and improves survival in breast cancer patients. Tai Chi Chuan is a complementary and alternative therapy that has become a widespread exercise worldwide. Tai Chi Chuan, a slow and graceful form of exercise and meditation, has been offered as the ideal exercise for breast cancer survivors. In recent years, Tai Chi Chuan as an adjuvant treatment of breast cancer postoperative adverse reactions, pays more and more attention to the relevant clinical.

q1.value: Does Tai Chi Chuan Improve Psychological Well-being and Quality of Life in Patients with Breast Cancer? Protocol for A Systematic Review of Randomized Controlled Trials

q2.value: Jing Guo, Yifeng Shen, Bin Li, Fei Wang, Yang Jiang, Yi Lin, Jianping Chen

q3.value: Breast cancer is now the most common cancer diagnosed in women and is the leading cause of deaths from cancer among women. Studies have shown that exercise reduces the risk of breast cancer development and improves survival in breast cancer patients. Tai Chi Chuan is a complementary and alternative therapy that has become a widespread exercise worldwide. Tai Chi Chuan, a slow and graceful form of exercise and meditation, has been offered as the ideal exercise for breast cancer survivors. In recent years, Tai Chi Chuan as an adjuvant treatment of breast cancer postoperative adverse reactions, pays more and more attention to the relevant clinical.

q4.value: Tai Chi Chuan is effective and safe for breast cancer. It can improve psychological well-being and quality of life in patients with breast cancer.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study summarizes and meta-analyzes all relevant randomized controlled trials on TCC in patients with breast cancer in the light of their anxiety, depression and fatigue level, inflammatory cytokine as well as quality of life, sleep quality and cognitive function. Randomized clinical trials will be included, both parallel and cross-over, will be included regardless of blinding, language and report type. The intervention includes any types of Tai Chi Chuan (TCC), such as Yang-style TCC, Chen-style TCC, Wu-style TCC, Sun-style TCC, 24 simplified TCC, and movements of TCC. Comparisons can be routine treatment including standard medication and/or conventional care program, other types of standard support therapy and non-exercise therapy. The following electronic databases will be searched: PubMed, Cochrane Library, EMBASE, Web of Science, CNKI, CBM, VIP, and Wan Fang Data. The methodologic quality of RCTs has been assessed using the Cochrane risk assessment tool. All trials included are analyzed according to the criteria of the Cochrane Handbook. Review Manager 5.3, R-3.5.1 software and GRADE pro-GDT online software are used for data synthesis and analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Database search
Four English medical databases (Cochrane Library, PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science) and four Chinese medical databases (China National Knowledge Infrastructure Database (CNKI), Chinese Biomedical Literature Database (CBM), VIP Chinese Science and Technology Periodical Database (VIP) and Wan Fang Data will be systematically searched from their inceptions up to February 2020. The search strategy will be based on the guidance of the Cochrane handbook. The following search terms of the databases in various relevant combinations are used to screen potential studies: (breast cancer OR breast neoplasm OR breast carcinoma OR breast tumor) AND (Tai Chi OR Tai Chi Chuan OR Tai Ji OR Tai Ji Quan OR Taiji OR Tai-ji OR Taijiquan) AND (random*). All relevant publications including academic dissertation and conference will be researched to ensure comprehensiveness. 
Inclusion Criteria
Types of studies.  Only relevant randomized controlled trials (RCTs) will be included.
Types of participants.  All of the participants must be female older than 18 and have been diagnosed as primary breast cancer stage 0-III patients. The main treatments the participants are currently receiving include any one of the following: surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormone therapy. Additionally, the participants should be under no physical limitation prohibiting exercise.
Types of intervention.  The experimental group is treated with TCC. Any type of TCC will be eligible, disregarding the styles (such as Yang-style TCC, Chen-style TCC, Wu-style TCC, Sun-style TCC) or forms (such as 24-form, 36-form, 48-form,104-form). Comparisons can be routine treatment including standard medication and/or conventional care program, other types of standard support therapy and non-exercise therapy. All interventions will be treated for no less than 12 weeks with a frequency of at least once per week.
Types of outcome measures.  Primary Outcomes: Psychological symptoms (depression and anxiety) and quality of life have been considered as the primary outcome. Secondary Outcomes: The secondary outcome assessments consist of fatigue, sleep quality, cognitive function, and inflammatory cytokine. The time endpoint of the above outcomes will be no earlier than 12 weeks after initiation of treatment.
Exclusion Criteria
(1) The unrelated and duplicated documents will be deleted.
(2) Reviews, theoretical discussions, experience summaries, and case reports will not be considered.
(3) The non-TCC type of intervention and articles without the original data will be not be included.
Data Collection and Extraction
Study screening and data extraction were based on the Cochrane collaborative network system evaluator handbook. NoteExpress (version:3.2, Beijing Aegean Software Company) software for literature import and screening was used to exclude duplicate literature, and to exclude unrelated literature by reading the titles and abstracts. Full texts that retain the randomized clinical trials meeting the inclusion criteria will be read. Two reviewers (GJ and SYF) will extract the data independently by adopting a self-developed data extraction form. Any disagreement in the process will be resolved by discussion with another team member (LB).
The following characteristics and data from each included study will be extracted. The general information will include research ID (primary author, year of publication, country of origin), title, publication status, report sources, fund support. Methodology information will include the design, number of arms, random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding, incomplete outcome data, selective reporting, sample size calculation, baseline comparability. For participant information, it will include the diagnostic criteria, inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, sample size, age, population, and status of cancer. Intervention information will include the type of intervention, current treatment, duration and frequency of treatment, intervention instructor and patient follow-up (reasons and number of patients who dropped out or got lost). Inclusion of all relevant outcome indicators ensures a comprehensive coverage.  
The selection process is shown in a PRISMA flow chart (http://www.prisma-statement.org/) (Figure 1). 
2.5 Assessment of methodological quality
Risk of bias will be assessed by the Cochrane risk assessment tool in the following domains: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of the participants and personnel, blinding of outcomes assessment, incomplete outcome data, selective outcome reporting, and other bias. Two reviewers (GJ and SYF) will independently assess the risk of bias for each included study. The low risk of bias, high risk of bias and unclear risk of bias will be used as a code for the evaluations of the above 7 domains. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion. If necessary, we will contact the authors of the included studies to get some missing information. Trials with a high risk of bias will be considered for sensitivity analysis.
Database search will be completed by February 2020, literature screening will be completed by March 2020, data collection and extraction and trials methodological quality evaluation will be completed by May 2020.

q13.value: In the absence of a sample size requirement, all RCTs that meet the inclusion criteria that do not meet the exclusion criteria will be included.

question.value:
Primary Outcomes: Psychological symptoms (depression and anxiety) and quality of life have been considered as the primary outcome. 
Secondary Outcomes: The secondary outcome assessments consist of fatigue, sleep quality, cognitive function, and inflammatory cytokine. The time endpoint of the above outcomes will be no earlier than 12 weeks after initiation of treatment.

Review Manager Software will be applied to analyze and synthesize the outcome measures systematically. The quantitative synthesis will be conducted on the outcomes when clinical heterogeneity is not considered by at least two reviewers in a discussion and qualitative description is adopted if clinical heterogeneity exists. Continuous variable is described by mean difference (MD), P-value and 95% confidence interval (CI). The relative risk (RR), P-value and 95%CI are used to describe the dichotomous outcomes. I2 test is used to judge the heterogeneity of meta-analysis. I2 value >50% is considered as significant heterogeneity. In this case, the data will be analyzed using a random-effect model. Otherwise, the fixed-effect model should be adopted. Sensitivity analysis is adopted to ensure the stability results by eliminating low-quality trials. If the necessary data are available, the grouping factor for subgroup analysis will be done for different duration or frequency of Tai Chi Chuan intervention.

attributes.title: Effects of Genetic Endowments, Parents’ Socioeconomic Status, and Gene-Environment Interaction on Spouse Pairing Patterns in the United States: Insights from Genetic Data
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Details of analysis will be specified in a newer registration.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The influence of concern about falling down the socioeconomic hierarchy on intergroup attitudes and behavior (Study 2)

other.value: We will also conduct exploratory analyses of our data. We will include additional measures (direct outcomes, mediators). A secondary aim of this study is to explore potential mediators (e.g., zero-sum beliefs, perceived competition) that might be driving the relationship between concern about downward mobility and our primary outcomes of interest. These exploratory analyses will conduct mediation analyses exploring the hypothesis that concerns about downward mobility among higher SES participants will increase their perceived competition (e.g., zero-sum beliefs, status threat, and perceived competition), and in turn influence the primary outcomes of interest. Exploratory analyses may also consider whether controlling for important variables (e.g., race-ethnicity) influences the relationship among the primary variables of interest.

sample.value: We will aim to recruit 500 participants. A power analysis using the G*Power computer program indicated that a total sample of 432 people would be needed to detect small-medium effects (Effect size f =.15) with 80% power to detect main effects and interaction. Sampling 500 students gives us flexibility to still reach desired power if students are unable to complete the study or we need to exclude any data.

analyses.value:
1)	As a manipulation check, we will ask students about their perceived concern with the possibility of experiencing downward socioeconomic mobility. We hypothesize that students randomly assigned to the downward mobility trend condition will indicate a greater level of concern with the possibility of experiencing downward socioeconomic mobility than students randomly assigned to control conditions. An ANOVA on students’ concern with the possibility of experiencing downward socioeconomic mobility will be conducted to examine if the analyses yield significant variation among conditions. A post hoc LSD test will then be conducted to reveal whether students in the downward mobility condition were more concerned with downward mobility than students in the upward mobility active comparison condition and students in the control condition.
2)	To examine the impact of the manipulated downward mobility beliefs on our primary outcomes (support for policies/initiatives that might benefit people from lower SES backgrounds; personal involvement/motivation to get personally involved in collective social action that would benefit people from lower SES backgrounds; perceived competition) we will conduct multiple regression analyses that include two orthogonal contrasts. The first contrast (C1) will oppose the downward mobility condition to both passive control and upward mobility control conditions combined. The residual contrast (C2) will oppose the passive control condition to the active control condition, with the downward mobility condition coded as 0. When we run the regression, we will examine if there are significant main effects of CC1, CC2, or socioeconomic status (SES), and if there is a significant condition*SES interaction for each of the outcomes listed above. We will then break down this interaction by examining if there is a main effect of CC1 (primary) and/or CC2 (secondary) among lower- and higher-SES individuals separately.

outliers.value: There will be one attention check asking all participants to respond to the following item, “This item is here to screen out random responding; please give a three as a response to this item.” Participants who are randomly assigned to either the downward mobility condition or the active comparison condition will also be exposed to two additional attention checks. These items will ask questions related to the manipulation. Specifically, one item will ask, “How many Americans (in the millions) are experiencing [upward/downward] socioeconomic mobility?” The correct response is 83 million. The second item will state “Americans are experiencing [upward/downward] socioeconomic mobility. Is this true or false?” The correct answer is true. We may exclude participants who failed these attention checks. However, we will conduct analysis of the data including those individuals who fail these attention checks before we conduct analysis of the data after excluding them. If results are similar, we will keep the entire sample.

dependent.value:
A)	Concern about downward socioeconomic mobility – Scale 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree)
a.	“I think it’s possible that I will move down the socioeconomic ladder.”
b.	“I am concerned with the possibility of experiencing a decline or decrease in socioeconomic status.”
c.	“It is likely that I will be in the group of people who will move down the socioeconomic ladder in the future.”

B)	Support for policies/initiatives that might benefit individuals from lower socioeconomic status backgrounds (e.g., first-generation low-income college students)
Please indicate your level of support for the following policies. Some items represent initiatives at [] University and some are more representative of broader U.S. society. Scale from 1 (strongly oppose) – 4 (strongly support).

-	“Undergraduate tuition fees, and room and board changes, at [] University will increase 3.5 percent for the 2019-20 academic year. This will allow [] to provide increased funds for students from low-income families.”
-	“Quotas, that is, setting aside places for certain groups.”
-	“Government sponsored healthcare for everybody.”
-	“Low income housing.”
-	“Reduced benefits for the unemployed.” 
-	“Increased taxation of the rich.”

C)	Personal involvement (motivation to get personally involved in collective social action)
a.	“I would be willing to sign a petition to call for more economic support for first-generation low-income students.”
b.	“I would be willing to get personally involved to improve the economic and social situation of first-generation low-income students at my college/university (e.g., pay greater activity fees).” 

D)	Perceived Competition
a.	We will examine participants perceived competition with different items meant to capture their zero-sum beliefs, perceived competition generally, and status threat.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions. Participants’ beliefs about socioeconomic mobility will be manipulated using a brief report and accompanying figure describing current socioeconomic mobility trends in the United States. In the downward mobility condition, participants will read a report indicating that “An estimated over 83 million Americans, across all backgrounds, experience downward socioeconomic mobility in the United States.” The accompanying figure will depict arrows displaying downward mobility trends from a higher position on the SES ladder to a lower position. In an active comparison condition, participants will read a report indicating that “An estimated over 83 million Americans, across all backgrounds, experience upward socioeconomic mobility in the United States.” The accompanying figure will depict arrows displaying upward mobility trends from a lower position on the SES ladder to a higher position. Participants in a passive control condition will not be exposed to any information about socioeconomic mobility.

hypothesis.value: The present research will examine whether individuals from higher socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds who are exposed to information increasing their concern about the possibility of experiencing downward socioeconomic mobility will: a) display less support for policies/initiatives that might benefit people from lower SES backgrounds (e.g., first-generation low income college students); b) display lower personal involvement/motivation to get personally involved in collective social action that would benefit people from lower SES backgrounds (e.g., first-generation low income college students); and c) display greater perceived competition.

The residual contrast (C2) will oppose the passive control condition to the active control condition, with the downward mobility condition coded as 0. When we run the regression, we will examine if there are significant main effects of CC1, CC2, or socioeconomic status (SES), and if there is a significant condition*SES interaction for each of the outcomes listed above. We will then break down this interaction by examining if there is a main effect of CC1 (primary) and/or CC2 (secondary) among lower- and higher-SES individuals separately.
registration_responses.outliers: There will be one attention check asking all participants to respond to the following item, “This item is here to screen out random responding; please give a three as a response to this item.” Participants who are randomly assigned to either the downward mobility condition or the active comparison condition will also be exposed to two additional attention checks. These items will ask questions related to the manipulation. Specifically, one item will ask, “How many Americans (in the millions) are experiencing [upward/downward] socioeconomic mobility?” The correct response is 83 million. The second item will state “Americans are experiencing [upward/downward] socioeconomic mobility. Is this true or false?” The correct answer is true. We may exclude participants who failed these attention checks. However, we will conduct analysis of the data including those individuals who fail these attention checks before we conduct analysis of the data after excluding them. If results are similar, we will keep the entire sample.
registration_responses.dependent:
A)	Concern about downward socioeconomic mobility – Scale 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree)
a.	“I think it’s possible that I will move down the socioeconomic ladder.”
b.	“I am concerned with the possibility of experiencing a decline or decrease in socioeconomic status.”
c.	“It is likely that I will be in the group of people who will move down the socioeconomic ladder in the future.”

B)	Support for policies/initiatives that might benefit individuals from lower socioeconomic status backgrounds (e.g., first-generation low-income college students)
Please indicate your level of support for the following policies. Some items represent initiatives at [] University and some are more representative of broader U.S. society. Scale from 1 (strongly oppose) – 4 (strongly support).

-	“Undergraduate tuition fees, and room and board changes, at [] University will increase 3.5 percent for the 2019-20 academic year. This will allow [] to provide increased funds for students from low-income families.”
-	“Quotas, that is, setting aside places for certain groups.”
-	“Government sponsored healthcare for everybody.”
-	“Low income housing.”
-	“Reduced benefits for the unemployed.” 
-	“Increased taxation of the rich.”

C)	Personal involvement (motivation to get personally involved in collective social action)
a.	“I would be willing to sign a petition to call for more economic support for first-generation low-income students.”
b.	“I would be willing to get personally involved to improve the economic and social situation of first-generation low-income students at my college/university (e.g., pay greater activity fees).” 

D)	Perceived Competition
a.	We will examine participants perceived competition with different items meant to capture their zero-sum beliefs, perceived competition generally, and status threat.
registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions. Participants’ beliefs about socioeconomic mobility will be manipulated using a brief report and accompanying figure describing current socioeconomic mobility trends in the United States. In the downward mobility condition, participants will read a report indicating that “An estimated over 83 million Americans, across all backgrounds, experience downward socioeconomic mobility in the United States.” The accompanying figure will depict arrows displaying downward mobility trends from a higher position on the SES ladder to a lower position. In an active comparison condition, participants will read a report indicating that “An estimated over 83 million Americans, across all backgrounds, experience upward socioeconomic mobility in the United States.” The accompanying figure will depict arrows displaying upward mobility trends from a lower position on the SES ladder to a higher position. Participants in a passive control condition will not be exposed to any information about socioeconomic mobility.
registration_responses.hypothesis: The present research will examine whether individuals from higher socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds who are exposed to information increasing their concern about the possibility of experiencing downward socioeconomic mobility will: a) display less support for policies/initiatives that might benefit people from lower SES backgrounds (e.g., first-generation low income college students); b) display lower personal involvement/motivation to get personally involved in collective social action that would benefit people from lower SES backgrounds (e.g., first-generation low income college students); and c) display greater perceived competition.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Status and Organizing: An evaluation of the impact of the status of organizers on willingness to do organizing work and the perceived importance of that work.

other.value: The data was originally collected as part of an omnibus survey on 17 December. I have not been granted access to this data yet. Once the pre-registration is accepted, I will contact the administrators of the omnibus survey for access to the data.

sample.value: Both Lucid and SSI are commissioned to provide samples. 1000 from Lucid and 1000 SSI respondents.

analyses.value:
I will examine the differences in means between the two primary outcome for the primary treatment/control (Obama). 

I will further examine if treatment effected associated intelligences and the gender of the work. 

As a manipulation check I will see if the treatment effected the perceived relative difficulty and the perceived relative status of organizing, as well as if it affected the awareness of what organizing is. 

I will finally evaluate how asking about emotional intelligence and gender before outcomes of interest effects the perceived relative difficulty, status, importance, and willingness to do organizing.

outliers.value: Screener questions are included in the omnibus to evaluate whether respondents are paying attention. While the primary analysis will be on the full sample, a robustness check will be to evaluate only that part of the sample which passed the screener.

dependent.value:
Importance to Organize: Relative reported importance of "community organizing" activities compared to the activities of 6 other politics related jobs. 

Willingness to Organize: Relative reported willingness to be a "community organizer" compared to 6 other politics related jobs.

conditions.value:
The primary treatment splits participants into two groups: those who are exposed to a "high status organizer" (Obama) and those who are not. This is the "main analysis". 

In addition three blocks of questions are order randomized: (A) Primary Outcomes of Interest, (B) Gender and Organizing, and (C) Intelligence and Organizing. 

This creates four additional "conditions" of potential interest within each treatment category. A first, B before A, C before A, and B & C before A. 

This is factorial 2:4.

hypothesis.value: Does the status of "organizing" influence people's perceptions of the importance of organizing and their willingness to organize.

question2a.value:
a. Differently weighted relational statements (within-subjects) and greek identity (between subjects). Levels of relational statements are weighted by greek identity.
 
b. Orthogonal relationships

question8b.value:
Participants who do not report their greek identity (a key IV) will not be included in analyses.
Participants who report being in an academic fraternity/sorority will not be included in analyses. 
Participants who check the same answer to every question.	
Nonsense answers to open-ended questions.

question1a.value:
This study is a conceptual replication of Study 1, extending the pattern to another chosen identity (greek life - fraternity/sorority involvement). As in Study 1, we hypothesize that participants will weight the statements asymmetrically based on their group membership (greek vs. non-greek), such that:

1. greek participants will agree more with greek-weighted statements than non-greek-weighted statements
2. greek participants will agree more with greek-weighted statements than non-greek participants
3. non-greek participants will agree more with non-greek weighted statements than greek-weighed statements
4. non-greek participants will agree more with non-greek weighed statements than greek participants 

A secondary hypothesis is that, replicating Study 1, identity centrality will moderate statement agreement, such that people who more strongly identify with their group (either greek or non-greek) will be more likely to agree with the statement weighted toward their group.

question2a.value: We expect there to be a crossover interaction between group membership and statement weighting, such that high greek identity participants are more likely to agree with greek identity weighted (and less likely to agree with non-greek identity weighted) statements and non-greek identity participants are more likely to agree with non-greek identity weighted (and less likely to agree with greek identity weighted) statements.

question3a.value: This is a conceptual replication of S1, thus the manipulated variable (weighted statements) has demonstrated the predicted interaction.

question5a.value: Tversky (1977) used contrast modeling to examine the directionality and asymmetry of relational statements. The characterization of stimuli as feature sets has been investigated in the analysis of many cognitive processes such as preferential choice (Tversky, 1972), semantic judgment (Smith, Shoben, & Rips, 1974), and matching function (Tversky, 1977). For example, why would people say “my love is as deep as the ocean”, but never “the ocean is as deep as my love”? Tversky argued that this is due to the way in which people weight the words based on their semantic ordering in the statement. We plan to build on this work by integrating contrast modeling with social identity research. Specifically, we will examine if group membership elicits asymmetrical weighting of relational sentences. Context is important in the weighting of statements in contrast modeling (Janowicz et al., 2010; Evers & Lakens, 2014). Based on the context provided by group membership like political affiliation or gender, we believe individuals use contrast modeling in their agreement or disagreement with the relational statements because their group membership will act as a similarity metric.

question1c.value: Average agreement with the relational statements will be calculated separately for statement groups (greek vs. non-greek). Statements will be aggregated by trait group (e.g., competency, warmth). From these aggregates, an overall measure of the level of agreement for statement groups will be calculated from a reliability analysis of all trait measures. If any particular items bring the scale reliability (Chronbach’s alpha) below .65, those specific items will be omitted from the relevant aggregate.

question2c.value:
We will test our prediction using a 2 (Statement weight: greek, non-greek) x 2 (Greek identity: greek, non-greek) mixed model ANOVA, where statement weight is within-subjects, while greek identity is between-subjects. 

Interaction effects will be followed-up using simple effects tests/pairwise comparisons in SPSS (LSD tests) to test each hypothesis above.

question3c.value:
IV: Weighted statements, and greek identity
DV: Level of agreement with statements

question1c.value: Identity centrality will be calculated based on an adaptation of Cameron (2004). This adaptation will be based on face-validity and sensibility based on this context. In a 10-item scale, participants will state agreement with statements on a scale of 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor). If any particular items bring the scale reliability (Chronbach’s alpha) below .65, those specific items will be omitted from the relevant aggregate.

question2c.value: We will test our prediction using two separate moderated regression analyses, one testing the relationships for greek participants, and another testing the relationships for non-greek participants. In each analysis, identity centrality will be treated as a continuous moderator in SPSS using MEMORE, a macro for SPSS that models moderation for within-subjects/repeated measures designs, where statement weight is within-subjects and identity centrality is between subjects. Neiman Johnson comparisons will be tested to determine the region of significance.

question3c.value:
IV: Weighted statements and greek affiliation
DV: Level of agreement with statements 
Moderator: Identity Centrality

attributes.title: 1.1.	Pre-existing conditions as risk factors for recovery of function following head injury

q1.value: 1.1.	Pre-existing conditions as risk factors for recovery of function following head injury

q3.value: Prior research examining the impact of selection bias in traumatic brain injury (TBI) research studies notes that utilization of overly-restrictive exclusion criteria can eliminate the variability imparted by the presence of pre-existing conditions (PECs), and impact understanding of injury and recovery mechanisms. Given the growing importance of understanding how the presence of PECs can contribute to the heterogeneity of TBI recovery trajectories, we seek to understand how patients with PECs present to emergency departments across the state of Pennsylvania, and how these PECs impact the course of one’s hospital stay and functional status at outcome, in comparison to trauma patients admitted without a diagnosed head injury.

q4.value:
1. Mortality rate and days spent in the hospital will be positively correlated with the quantity of PECs.
2. TBI patients with a greater number of PECs will perform worse on measures of independence, compared to TBI patients with fewer PECs. 
3. Are there any PECs that predict particularly poor outcome in the elderly TBI? 
4. Exploratory questions
a. How has the prevalence and incidence of PECs at the time of injury changed over time in the state of Pennsylvania?
b. If a patient is admitted without documented PECs, what are the expected outcomes for elderly TBI?
c. Of those patients admitted to the participating Pennsylvania hospitals, are there specific characteristics of head-injured patients presenting with an increasing number of pre-existing conditions (PECs)?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Retrospective cohort study. The analyses proposed here utilize data from an existing database collected by the Pennsylvania Trauma Systems Foundation (PTSF).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The PTSF serves as the governing body overseeing accreditation of trauma centers throughout the state of Pennsylvania. Beginning in October 1986, the PTSF initiated a trauma registry (Pennsylvania Trauma Outcome Study, or PTOS) to receive data from participating hospitals, in an effort to evaluate patient outcomes through research and education across comparable centers state-wide. To date, over 850,000 trauma patients and their associated data have been registered in the database. The PTSF has provided access to the database to the researchers listed in this proposal. Due to the immense size of the data, the researchers have only undertaken data cleaning efforts to ensure fidelity of the existing coded data. Summary statistics and hypotheses testing related to proposed analyses have not been conducted.

question.value: The data utilized in these analyses are drawn directly from the larger PTOS database. Although the PTOS data collection began in 1986, PECs were not entered in to the database until 1992. Therefore, these analyses will be performed on a subset of the data from 1992 to present. Observations collected 1992 to present will be divided in to two cohorts: trauma patients entering emergency departments with a documented head injury, and a second group of patients without a documented head injury at admission.

registration_responses.q3: Prior research examining the impact of selection bias in traumatic brain injury (TBI) research studies notes that utilization of overly-restrictive exclusion criteria can eliminate the variability imparted by the presence of pre-existing conditions (PECs), and impact understanding of injury and recovery mechanisms. Given the growing importance of understanding how the presence of PECs can contribute to the heterogeneity of TBI recovery trajectories, we seek to understand how patients with PECs present to emergency departments across the state of Pennsylvania, and how these PECs impact the course of one’s hospital stay and functional status at outcome, in comparison to trauma patients admitted without a diagnosed head injury.

q1.value: Moorean and evaluative incoherencies: an experimental approach

q2.value: Andres Soria Ruiz, Nils Franzén, Mora Maldonado

q3.value:
Expressivists in metaethics maintain that moral statements do not serve to describe the world, but that their function instead is to express that the speaker is in a certain conative or affective state of mind. 

The contrast between moral and non-moral statements is sometimes presented as the idea that, whereas non-moral statements express cognitive mental states such as belief, moral statements express non-cognitive mental states, such as approval. Moreover, the latter express non-cognitive states in the same way that non-moral statements express beliefs. This is Schroeder's 'Parity Thesis':

'[M]oral sentences are related to noncognitive, desire‐like states of mind in the same way that ordinary descriptive sentences are related to ordinary beliefs—they express them. (Schroeder, 2008, p. 3). 

The Parity Thesis makes a testable prediction: if moral assertions express non-cognitive attitudes in the same way that non-moral assertions express beliefs, then whatever relations hold between non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions should hold as well between moral assertions and ascriptions of the relevant non-cognitive attitudes. In particular, just as certain combinations of non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions generate so-called Moore paradoxes (1), similar combinations of moral assertions and ascriptions of non-cognitive attitudes ought to generate analogously unacceptable constructions (2).

(1) Murder is wrong but I don’t think it is wrong.
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.

Woods (2014) claims that this is not the case: sentences like (2) are not unacceptable in the same way that Moorean paradoxes are. He argues that this constitutes a major blow to the Parity Thesis. Woods, however, bases his claim that sentences like (2) are acceptable on his intuitions. But intuitions vary, and not everyone agrees with Woods on this score. 

The purpose of our study is to empirically test the acceptability of sentences like (2), and thereby provide empirical evidence that speaks to Wood's claim, the Parity Thesis, and the connection between moral language and non-cognitive attitudes that is the focus of much contemporary literature on metaethics and philosophy of language.

q4.value:
We have two hypothesis: either sentences like (2) (henceforth 'evaluative incoherencies') are acceptable or they are not.  

To test these hypotheses, we will study the acceptability of statements constructed following this template: where x is an individual-referring term and A is a propositional attitude verb,

Murder is wrong but x does not A {that murder is wrong / murder}

We will manipulate two factors on constructions that follow this template:
(a) Attitude: A will stand for 'think' or 'disapprove of' (thus the variability between assigning a full propositional clause or just a noun)
(b) Person: x will be the speaker ('I') or a third person ('Ann')

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong but I don't think that it is wrong.           (Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.                    (Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. (Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          (Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Given the type of constructions that we will test, our hypotheses can be spelled out more concretely in the following research questions:

(i) Are sentences like (1)/(2) significantly less acceptable than their third-personal counterparts (3)/(4)? In other words, is the Person factor a good predictor of acceptability of these constructions (modulo potential interactions)?

(ii) Is the difference in acceptability between sentences like (1) and (3) similar to the difference in acceptability between sentences like (2) and (4)? That is, is there an interaction between the Person and Attitude factors?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
We have a within-subjects design with 2 factors: Person (levels: first/third) and Attitude (levels: think/disapprove).  The combination of these two factors gives rise to four sentence configurations, repeated in (1-4) below from above:

(1) Murder is wrong but I don't think that it is wrong.           (Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.                    (Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. (Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          (Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Each participant will be shown a set of 16 sentences, and for each sentence they will be asked whether they think that the sentence makes sense or not.

The 16 sentences are generated by taking the following 4 moral sentences (5)-(8) and coupling them with attitude ascriptions in the way above-described. 

(5) Murder is wrong.
(6) Volunteering is wrong.
(7) Eating meat is wrong.
(8) What she did is wrong.

The variation in the action under evaluation (murder, volunteering, etc.) is motivated by trying to make sure that participants' personal opinions about the types of action under consideration do not interfere with their judgment about the acceptability of the relevant constructions. To this effect, we include a type of act which is generally taken to be wrong (murder), a type of act which is generally taken not to be wrong (volunteering) and a type of act whose status is currently debated (eating meat); as well as an action token (what she did) whose details are unknown to participants.

question.value:
Our study will manipulate two between-subject variables with two levels each:
(a) Person: whether the person to whom an attitude is ascribed is the 1st or a 3rd person.
(b) Attitude: whether the attitude ascribed is belief or disapproval.

We will expose participants to constructions and we will ask them whether they take each construction to make sense or not.

This will give rise to a single, binary variable to be measured: whether participants find each construction sensical or not.
Participants' responses, as they are binary, will be mapped into 0 ('it doesn't make sense') or 1 ('it makes sense').

We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results. We will run three analyses:

1) We aim to show whether the manipulated variable 'Person' is a good predictor of the acceptability of test items. 

To show this, we will do an omnibus model that tests the effect of variable Person on the responses, together with the effect of variable Attitude and of the interaction between Person and Attitude (omnibus model: response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude). 

We aim to see whether this model is better at predicting participants' responses than an otherwise similar model that does not take into account variable Person (response ~ Attitude + Person*Attitude). This would show that there is a main effect of Person in the presence of other higher-order interactions. 

Both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

2) We aim to show whether there is an interaction effect of the Person and Attitude variables.

In order to show this, we will compare the above-described omnibus model (response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude) with an otherwise similar model that does not take into account the interaction between Person and Attitude (response ~ Person + Attitude). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

3) We want to show that not only paradoxical sentences are worse than non-paradoxical ones but that they are below what one would expect by chance (below 50% of approval rate). 

We will subset the data to sentences in the 'disapprove' level of the Attitude factor and evaluate the effect of the Person manipulation on the responses: Response ~ Coherence +(Coherence|subject). We will use a treatment contrast coding with baseline for first Person.

q21.value:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  

For the first two analyses, we will obtain p-values from a chi-square likelihood test comparing the full model to a reduced one in which the relevant predictor (Person or Interaction depending on the case) was removed. 

For the third analysis, we will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of selecting the response one response over other is significantly different from 0 in the baseline condition (for the first person), i.e., that the frequency with which participants say 'makes sense'/'doesn't make sense' to first person sentences significantly different from 50%. The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more 'make sense' responses and negative ones more 'doesn't make sense'

The intercepts for this model is predicted to be significant and negative: participants are expected to say 'doesn't make sense'  for First person evaluative sentences. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether responses in the Third person condition were different from the baseline (First person). This difference is expected to be significant.

q23.value: We don't expect any missing data (forced choice task).

q24.value:
In further analyses, we might want to look at another variable:
- Object-of-evaluation effects. That is, the impact of picking out different objects of evaluation for our test items. As explained in the design plan, we will have items with different types of objects of evaluation (murder, volunteering, eating meat and what-she-did). This suggests two parameters for potential scrutiny: 
(a) participants' knowledge of the act under evaluation (i.e., murder / volunteering / eating meat vs. what-she-did); and 
(b) participants' antecedent opinions about the type of act under consideration (murder vs. volunteering vs. eating meat).

A related issue for future work—which we will not explore based on our data but which it would be good to mention here—is the possibility that Moore paradoxes constructed with moral sentences ('murder is wrong but I don't think it is wrong') may turn out to be less unacceptable than Moorean paradoxes constructed with non-moral sentences ('it's raining but I don't think that it is raining'). Since we will not be testing the latter type of constructions in this study, this will not concern us. However, if our data shows that Moorean paradoxes with moral sentences are more acceptable than we would otherwise have suspected, this may motivate a further study targeting the role of moral sentences in these constructions.

registration_responses.q1: Moorean and evaluative incoherencies: an experimental approach
registration_responses.q2: Andres Soria Ruiz, Nils Franzén, Mora Maldonado
registration_responses.q3:
Expressivists in metaethics maintain that moral statements do not serve to describe the world, but that their function instead is to express that the speaker is in a certain conative or affective state of mind. 

The contrast between moral and non-moral statements is sometimes presented as the idea that, whereas non-moral statements express cognitive mental states such as belief, moral statements express non-cognitive mental states, such as approval. Moreover, the latter express non-cognitive states in the same way that non-moral statements express beliefs. This is Schroeder's 'Parity Thesis':

'[M]oral sentences are related to noncognitive, desire‐like states of mind in the same way that ordinary descriptive sentences are related to ordinary beliefs—they express them. (Schroeder, 2008, p. 3). 

The Parity Thesis makes a testable prediction: if moral assertions express non-cognitive attitudes in the same way that non-moral assertions express beliefs, then whatever relations hold between non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions should hold as well between moral assertions and ascriptions of the relevant non-cognitive attitudes. In particular, just as certain combinations of non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions generate so-called Moore paradoxes (1), similar combinations of moral assertions and ascriptions of non-cognitive attitudes ought to generate analogously unacceptable constructions (2).

(1) Murder is wrong but I don’t think it is wrong.
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.

Woods (2014) claims that this is not the case: sentences like (2) are not unacceptable in the same way that Moorean paradoxes are. He argues that this constitutes a major blow to the Parity Thesis. Woods, however, bases his claim that sentences like (2) are acceptable on his intuitions. But intuitions vary, and not everyone agrees with Woods on this score. 

The purpose of our study is to empirically test the acceptability of sentences like (2), and thereby provide empirical evidence that speaks to Wood's claim, the Parity Thesis, and the connection between moral language and non-cognitive attitudes that is the focus of much contemporary literature on metaethics and philosophy of language.
registration_responses.q4:
We have two hypothesis: either sentences like (2) (henceforth 'evaluative incoherencies') are acceptable or they are not.  

To test these hypotheses, we will study the acceptability of statements constructed following this template: where x is an individual-referring term and A is a propositional attitude verb,

Murder is wrong but x does not A {that murder is wrong / murder}

We will manipulate two factors on constructions that follow this template:
(a) Attitude: A will stand for 'think' or 'disapprove of' (thus the variability between assigning a full propositional clause or just a noun)
(b) Person: x will be the speaker ('I') or a third person ('Ann')

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong but I don't think that it is wrong.           (Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.                    (Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. (Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          (Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Given the type of constructions that we will test, our hypotheses can be spelled out more concretely in the following research questions:

(i) Are sentences like (1)/(2) significantly less acceptable than their third-personal counterparts (3)/(4)? In other words, is the Person factor a good predictor of acceptability of these constructions (modulo potential interactions)?

(ii) Is the difference in acceptability between sentences like (1) and (3) similar to the difference in acceptability between sentences like (2) and (4)? That is, is there an interaction between the Person and Attitude factors?

registration_responses.q21:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  

For the first two analyses, we will obtain p-values from a chi-square likelihood test comparing the full model to a reduced one in which the relevant predictor (Person or Interaction depending on the case) was removed. 

For the third analysis, we will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of selecting the response one response over other is significantly different from 0 in the baseline condition (for the first person), i.e., that the frequency with which participants say 'makes sense'/'doesn't make sense' to first person sentences significantly different from 50%. The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more 'make sense' responses and negative ones more 'doesn't make sense'

The intercepts for this model is predicted to be significant and negative: participants are expected to say 'doesn't make sense'  for First person evaluative sentences. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether responses in the Third person condition were different from the baseline (First person). This difference is expected to be significant.

registration_responses.q24:
In further analyses, we might want to look at another variable:
- Object-of-evaluation effects. That is, the impact of picking out different objects of evaluation for our test items. As explained in the design plan, we will have items with different types of objects of evaluation (murder, volunteering, eating meat and what-she-did). This suggests two parameters for potential scrutiny: 
(a) participants' knowledge of the act under evaluation (i.e., murder / volunteering / eating meat vs. what-she-did); and 
(b) participants' antecedent opinions about the type of act under consideration (murder vs. volunteering vs. eating meat).

A related issue for future work—which we will not explore based on our data but which it would be good to mention here—is the possibility that Moore paradoxes constructed with moral sentences ('murder is wrong but I don't think it is wrong') may turn out to be less unacceptable than Moorean paradoxes constructed with non-moral sentences ('it's raining but I don't think that it is raining'). Since we will not be testing the latter type of constructions in this study, this will not concern us. However, if our data shows that Moorean paradoxes with moral sentences are more acceptable than we would otherwise have suspected, this may motivate a further study targeting the role of moral sentences in these constructions.
registration_responses.q8.question:
We have a within-subjects design with 2 factors: Person (levels: first/third) and Attitude (levels: think/disapprove).  The combination of these two factors gives rise to four sentence configurations, repeated in (1-4) below from above:

(1) Murder is wrong but I don't think that it is wrong.           (Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.                    (Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. (Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          (Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Each participant will be shown a set of 16 sentences, and for each sentence they will be asked whether they think that the sentence makes sense or not.

The 16 sentences are generated by taking the following 4 moral sentences (5)-(8) and coupling them with attitude ascriptions in the way above-described. 

(5) Murder is wrong.
(6) Volunteering is wrong.
(7) Eating meat is wrong.
(8) What she did is wrong.

The variation in the action under evaluation (murder, volunteering, etc.) is motivated by trying to make sure that participants' personal opinions about the types of action under consideration do not interfere with their judgment about the acceptability of the relevant constructions. To this effect, we include a type of act which is generally taken to be wrong (murder), a type of act which is generally taken not to be wrong (volunteering) and a type of act whose status is currently debated (eating meat); as well as an action token (what she did) whose details are unknown to participants.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk and will be paid $0.5 for the their participation, which will take 5 minutes of their time. Participants will be excluded if they are not self-reported native English speakers.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Our study will manipulate two between-subject variables with two levels each:
(a) Person: whether the person to whom an attitude is ascribed is the 1st or a 3rd person.
(b) Attitude: whether the attitude ascribed is belief or disapproval.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will expose participants to constructions and we will ask them whether they take each construction to make sense or not.

This will give rise to a single, binary variable to be measured: whether participants find each construction sensical or not.
registration_responses.q18.question: Participants' responses, as they are binary, will be mapped into 0 ('it doesn't make sense') or 1 ('it makes sense').
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results. We will run three analyses:

1) We aim to show whether the manipulated variable 'Person' is a good predictor of the acceptability of test items. 

To show this, we will do an omnibus model that tests the effect of variable Person on the responses, together with the effect of variable Attitude and of the interaction between Person and Attitude (omnibus model: response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude). 

We aim to see whether this model is better at predicting participants' responses than an otherwise similar model that does not take into account variable Person (response ~ Attitude + Person*Attitude). This would show that there is a main effect of Person in the presence of other higher-order interactions. 

Both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

2) We aim to show whether there is an interaction effect of the Person and Attitude variables.

In order to show this, we will compare the above-described omnibus model (response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude) with an otherwise similar model that does not take into account the interaction between Person and Attitude (response ~ Person + Attitude). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

3) We want to show that not only paradoxical sentences are worse than non-paradoxical ones but that they are below what one would expect by chance (below 50% of approval rate). 

We will subset the data to sentences in the 'disapprove' level of the Attitude factor and evaluate the effect of the Person manipulation on the responses: Response ~ Coherence +(Coherence|subject). We will use a treatment contrast coding with baseline for first Person.
